I’ve got mandibular tori something fierce, like, to the point that I can’t even eat grapes without biting them in half first. Because if I forget and simply pop whole ones into my mouth, I’m almost guaranteed to get one stuck between these two crazy big lumps beneath my tongue and then I have to excuse myself to go find a private place where I can manually (and most ungraciously) extract the thing. Many foods do this to me; Grapes just happen to be the most common culprit. And in my 48 orbits around the sun, I’ve never been able to free anything thus trapped by any degree of lingual acrobatics. I always end up having to pry the item free with my fingers (or with chopsticks, which did work out for me on one occasion). My dentist tells me that they’re a residual trait likely related to tusks in ancient species, which has me wondering.. how many ancient beasties got food stuck in that heinous dead zone and had no fingers (or chopsticks) with which to pry it out? Those poor miserable beasties. -Phill, Las Vegas

Semantic satiation is the name of a psychological phenomenon wherein the repetition of a word, whether it's visual or oral, causes it to lose its meaning for the viewer/listener, and makes it seem like it's just a meaningless sound.

The songbird @5:00 is not singing, but open-mouth breathing, which indicates it's very stressed, either by heat, illness, or a perceived threat. Indications of this include it's posture (crouching is not a common position for a thrush while it's in song), the closed eyes (very sick/stressed birds close their eyes - healthy birds can't afford to close their eyes or they could miss a potential threat, especially not during song when they're already drawing attention to themselves), and the protruding tongue/glottis (commonly seen in open-mouth breathing, not so much in song). All these signs together tell me this bird is very stressed/sick, and is not singing.

I am SO EXCITED to see various education channels talking about these less-covered topics. Dinosaurs and to some extent pleistocene fauna tend to suck all the air out of the paleontology room in schools or pop science, leaving things like early proto-mammals, pre-pleistocene fauna, and the rise of flowering plants out entirely.
